title: BCG Vaccine, Live (PF) Percutaneous: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for BCG vaccine, live (PF) percutaneous on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is used to prevent [tuberculosis](https://www.webmd.com/lung/understanding-tuberculosis-basics) (TB) in people who have not been infected with the disease but are at a high risk of getting it. This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) is not used to treat tuberculosis.This vaccine contains live bacteria that have been weakened. It works by causing the body to produce its own protection ( [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing)) against the bacteria that causes tuberculosis.This form of the vaccine is not used to treat or prevent [bladder cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/bladder-cancer/understanding-bladder-cancer-basic-information). How to use BCG VACCINE (TICE STRAIN) Vial This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is given by injection into the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) by a [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. It is usually given as a single dose in the upper arm area. Dosage is based on your age. Side Effects Pain at the injection site or [swollen lymph nodes](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/swollen-lymph-nodes-topic-overview) may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. A small red bump may occur at the injection site. This bump will later crust and fall off 6 to 10 weeks later. A small, flat scar may remain. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional right away if you have any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your health care professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your health care professional right away if you have any serious side effects, including: [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) sores/bumps, pus at injection site, bone pain, signs of infection (fever that doesn't go away). A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before you receive this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as monosodium glutamate, polysorbate 80, latex), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before receiving this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment), burns or [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) disease over large area of [skin](https://www.webmd.com/beauty/nutrients-for-healthy-skin), positive tuberculin [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/picture-of-the-skin) test, current infection/fever. This vaccine is not recommended for use during pregnancy. Consult your health care professional for more details. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: [antibiotics](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-antibiotics-myths-facts) (such as drugs to treat [tuberculosis](https://www.webmd.com/lung/understanding-tuberculosis-basics) [ethambutol](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8082/ethambutol+oral/details), [pyrazinamide](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-7398/pyrazinamide+oral/details)), [mefloquine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-6081/mefloquine+oral/details). Other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) may be given at the same time as this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), but they should be given with separate syringes and at different injection sites. If the [BCG vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-154546/bcg+vaccine%2c+live+(pf)+percutaneous/details) cannot be given at the same time as other live [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), then it should be given at least 4 weeks later. This vaccine may interfere with the tuberculin [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq) test, possibly causing false test results. Before having this [skin](https://www.webmd.com/beauty/nutrients-for-healthy-skin) test, make sure that the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional knows that you have received this vaccine. Overdose Not applicable. As with any [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) may not fully protect everyone who receives it. Keep vaccine records for yourself and all of your children, and provide them to their [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professionals and to your children after they are grown. This will prevent unnecessary re- [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). Not applicable. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Protect from light. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
